required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Oxygen Reserve Index: Utility as Early Warning for Desaturation in Morbidly Obese Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Oxygen Reserve Index: Utility as Early Warning for Desaturation in Morbidly Obese Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The Oxygen Reserve Index (ORi) is a reference that could help clinicians with their assessments of normoxic and hyperoxic states by scaling the measured absorption information between 0.00 and 1.00. An ORi of 0.00 corresponds to partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) values of 100 mmHg and below and an ORi of 1.00 corresponds to PaO2 values of 200 mmHg and above. This is a prospective, observational, clinical study designed to evaluate the clinical utility of the Oxygen Reserve Index (ORI) as an early warning for arterial hemoglobin desaturation during the induction of general anesthesia and tracheal intubation in obese patients undergoing elective surgical procedures.

detailed_description.textblock: This IRB approved study obtained written informed consent from obese (body mass index (BMI) kg/m2; 30<BMI<40) and normal BMI (19<BMI<25) patients scheduled for elective surgery requiring general endotracheal anesthesia. An ORI sensor was placed in addition to standard monitors. Patients were pre-oxygenated with 100% FiO2. After ORI plateaued, general anesthesia was induced and endotracheal intubation accomplished using a videolaryngoscope. Patients remained apneic until SpO2 reached 94%, then were ventilated with 100% oxygen until ORI plateaued. ORI and arterial hemoglobin saturation were recorded continuously by an automated data capture system. Added warning time for critical desaturation was defined as the difference between the time to reach SpO2 94% from ORI alarm start or from SpO2 97%. Data are reported as median; 95% CI.

primary_outcome.description: Evaluate the clinical utility of the change in the oxygen reserve index as an early warning of impending arterial oxygen desaturation in obese patients

intervention.intervention_name: Masimo Radical-7 amd Root System with ORi Parameter
intervention.description: Masimo Radical-7 and Root System with ORi parameter in all subjects are enrolled in the test group and receive an ORi sensor during their elective surgery.
Masimo Radical-7 and Root System with ORi parameter in all subjects are enrolled in the test group and receive an ORi sensor during their elective surgery.

study_pop.textblock: Patients scheduled for elective surgical procedures in the UC Davis Medical Center main ORs will be screened for potential enrollment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age greater than 18 years
- BMI>30, <40 m/kg2
- Control group only: BMI >18.5 m/kg2, <25 m/kg2
- Scheduled for an elective surgical procedure requiring general anesthesia and endotracheal intubation
Exclusion Criteria
- Age less than 18 years
- Adults unable to give primary consent
- Pregnancy
- Prisoners

Applegate RL 2nd, Dorotta IL, Wells B, Juma D, Applegate PM. The Relationship Between Oxygen Reserve Index and Arterial Partial Pressure of Oxygen During Surgery. Anesth Analg. 2016 Sep;123(3):626-33. doi: 10.1213/ANE.0000000000001262.
